{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3548955,"name":"steinra","username":"steinra","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/steinra/{size}/3823_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T03:38:46.458Z","cooked":"

We are seeing several errors and have tried different things to solve. We stripped it down to just the drive template, and made sure we had realtime threads off and we did characterize the feed forwards for the drive.

Issues: The drive system was extremely laggy. Or unresponsive to inputs. May start OK and then degrade over time to sluggish movement.

Hardware: RoboRio 1 - moved to RoboRio 2. Rev Vortex motors and CAN Coders. Paired radios robot in bridge to one on desk acting as AP on 6G. Ethernet connected driver station to the desktop AP radio.

We are seeing multiple loop overruns and delayed loop processors. We will also see Advantage Scope just stop receiving data and pause and then do a quick catch up. The logged server drive states show major lag between setpoint and measured outputs.

Here are some errors.

ERROR 1 [AdvantageKit] Capacity of receiver queue exceeded, data will NOT be logged. org.littletonrobotics.junction.Logger.periodicAfterUser(Logger.java:369)

dc81e64a-75db-464a-a8e8-154a0befd9bb2048×1536 170 KB

188637d0-527d-4333-af7b-a6f3db0f77d92048×1536 168 KB

8f4aeead-6ab6-4eb3-969d-9f591fb8eb722048×1536 173 KB

Any things we can try to solve this?

We did just go to a default WPILib swerve template with PWM motor controllers. We saw the delay on entry for first time to teleop and auto of 90 ms and 50 ms, but that only occurred once and repeated enable and disable did not cause it to occur again.

OK not fully solved, but did make a step forward. The USB drive we were using to write the logs to was too slow. We pulled it and did not write to it and a large part of the overruns are gone. But we are still seeing some periodic overruns in just the base template.

Have new USB drives on order to see if that works tomorrow.

Can you post a log file where you see loop overruns? Keep in mind that occasional loop overruns should be expected on most robot projects, and are only an actual concern if they meaningfully affect the robot operation. In particular, they are likely to be a problem if the overruns are either very large (e.g. >50-100ms) or very frequent (e.g. >5-10 times per second).

We found it was indeed the USB drive for the logs bogging everything down. We pulled it and everything seemed to run better. Working to add code back in and we will see if we have other overrun issues. We do at start up but it seems to settle down after that.
